title: Find widget history lost from untitled file when the file is saved
body:
- Open new untitled file with some text
- Write complicated regex in find widget
- Save the file
- Open find widget, see that the find history is gone

But you can open a new untitled file to see the history. It seems like all untitled editors share find history and all real file editors share find history? Why are they separate?

title: Update README
body: added License badge

title: VS Code no longer supports 'edit' in 'git rebase' flow

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
As of a latest update, VS Code now does the wrong thing when using the Source Control pane during a `git rebase` command. `git rebase -i` allows the rebase to be stopped in in order to `edit` commits. This includes undoing them, changing the commit message, or adding more commits. Now, instead of just allowing commits as usual, VS Code attempts to use `git rebase --continue` after altering a commit, which fails because there is still a commit pending that is not the original.

- VSCode Version: 1.28.2 (system setup)
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise 1809 17763.55

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new branch, and add at least one commit to the branch.
2. In the terminal, do `git rebase -i master`
3. In the editor for the interactive rebase, change a commit from `pick` to `edit`
4. Close the editor.
5. Git will start the rebase, and stop on the commit. It will prompt to amend the commit or add more.
6. In the Source Control pane, use 'Undo last commit'
7. Once the commit is soft reset, attempt to edit the commit. Rename the commit description or make more local changes.
8. Note that VS Code shows a warning that editing the commit is not allowed, even though Git specifically allows it here.
9. Attempt to commit anyway through the Source Control pane.
10. VS Code pops a dialog from Git, saying that the operation is not allowed.
11. In the Git log, observe that the commit action actually sent `git rebase --continue`, which is not correct. It should have just done a usual `git commit`

One can work around the issue by completing the commit in the terminal window, but using VS Code normally handles the work of auto-staging files and deletions, making it a lot more useful.

![10 26 vs code git rebase edit blocked](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6828233/47572497-f5f41e80-d8ef-11e8-9200-8129e130bc2f.gif)

This used to work! If you want to be more helpful during rebases, I suggest adding a dedicated 'continue' button instead of altering the behavior of the commit button.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Drag and Drop text (still) copies it instead of moving
body:
I know this is a duplicate of #35453 and #54500, but those were closed and locked because it was considered fixed. I would like to report that the issue still happens.

- VSCode Version: 1.28.2 and 1.29.0-insiders
- OS Version:  Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Ctrl F (or Ctrl H as Swazimodo shows in #63139)
2. Esc
3. Select some text
4. Drag it

A work around is to tap the Ctrl key before dragging.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Integrated Terminal : Start named session
body:
Although renaming integrated terminal sessions is allowed (#10023), I can't find an easy way to automatically do it when you debug an application. When using "console": "integratedTerminal" in launch.json, it would be nice to have an "integratedTerminalName" attribute available.

This is specially useful, since currently is not possible to have multiple debug console windows and when running multi project and need to read each project output on a different window, navigation through the many terminals is hard, and renaming each manually after launching is a very repetitive and hard to do everytime task.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: I would like to be able to save the list of my enabled extensions and also be able to load it for a new vscode installation.

title: Cannot turn off HTML comment autocomplete
body:
This is infuriating.
When I am commenting out existing code, I have to continually delete the auto-completed extra code.

I type
`<!--`
And it becomes `<!---->`
This assumes I am about to write a new comment - nine times out of ten I am commenting out existing code.

Thank you

Paul

title: Allow to remap "Open to Side" from quick open
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> 
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.28.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.13.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open `Keyboard Shortcuts`
2. Use `Record Keys` to filter list by `ctrl + enter` mappings

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

I have managed to figure out that pressing `ctrl + enter` while a file is highlighted in the quick open list opens the highlighted file in a split. I want to remap this functionality to `ctrl + v`, but I don't know the command because as you can see from the screenshot below it doesn't show up as a command.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3773641/47547533-8dce2880-d941-11e8-98a8-f1ae4576bb2f.png)

Note that I have also double checked that none of the commands listed above are the correct one by trying 

```
{
       "key": "ctrl+v",
       "command": "<COMMAND>",
       "when": "inQuickOpen"
}
```

where <COMMAND> is one of the commands from the image above.

title: When you copy a line without any selection the \n should not be copied

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
- VSCode Version: 1.28.2
- OS Version: OSX 10.13.6

related bug: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/40695

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In the editor put cursor on a line and hit CTRL+C.
2. Now go the place you want paste the content and position the cursor in for example in the middle of two parenthesis.
3. Hit CRTL+V. You would expect the content to be pasted in between your two parenthesis. But it will create a new line on top of where you position the cursor and paste the line there. 

This is the default behavior of IntelliJ and PyCharm and it is really convenient. Copying one line of text generally means only the content of that line no the \n at the end.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes. same result without any extensions.

title: Remember previous window size and position per workspace
body:
I use VSCode to develop many projects, require to open many folders in different window in same time.
Again and again after opened folder in window I need to resize VSCode window and prepare them to previous position.
If possible I want VSCode can remember previous state of each opened folder.

body:
Hello,
I'm looking for a feature to use word wrap only for comments in golang, java and html.

It there any option do enable such feature? If yes, how can I set my settings to enable this behavior and if not, please understand it as feature request. 

Volker

title: MSIX installer

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
After 2 years of conversation in issue #10759 (Release in the Windows Store) I think this is the right time to reevaluate the request.

What we originally wanted is all the goodness of UWP lifecycle management (clean install/uninstall and updates received in the background without having to run the app), but now it's possible outside of the Store with MSIX packaging without having to comply with some of the stricter rules of the Store and resource/capability management of UWP apps.

So the proposal is simple: **Please make an MSIX installer for VS Code** even if it's not distributed through the Store (for numerous technical reasons).

As a first step, Windows 10 users would benefit from it, later, as MSIX is designed to be cross-platform, it can evolve into the only installer format on all platforms (Linux, macOS, Windows 7+) and as the Store evolves, it can be a good foundation to potentially publish VS Code to the Store.

title: VSCode deletes my files on samba share (Mac)
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.28.2
- OS Version: Mojave (10.14) and High Sierra (10.13.6)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Connect to a samba share (finder -> cmd-k -> connect)
2. Create a new file in VSCode and save it --or-- open and modify an existing file
3. Press cmd-s. One of two things will happen: (a) VSCode will do nothing (the file changed indication will remain but it won't be saved to the samba share) or (b) the file will disappear from the samba share and VSCode will display a ENOENT error message (with "retry as admin / save as / discard" options that do nothing).

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

This also occurs on a fresh installation after deleting "$HOME/Library/Application Support/Code" and "$HOME/.vscode".

title: Create a default launch configuration for launching E2E (Protractor) tests
body:
# Problem
I'm currently trying to set up Protractor with a new Angular 6 application with TypeScript in VSCode.
I've followed many many guides, stack overflow questions, issues on Github for VSCode and Angular, and went through the Angular.io website.

I still cannot get protractor set up cleanly with my setup.
Protractor comes with new Angular applications.
I was shocked to not see a section on it in the Angular.io docs; unit and component tests are covered but e2e are not.

VSCode does not have a default Launch Configuration for Protractor which is surprising, seeing as Mocha, Yeoman, Gulp, and others have a default launch configuration. 
I think Protractor should have one too.

# Solution
We add a default launch configuration option for Protractor.
This would help people set up and use Protractor for their new Angular application in VSCode.

title: Need a shortcut key binging of outline to toggle expanding or folding
body:
It's necessary for me using a shortcut to toggle the outline view.  I think it well be better if it has a key binging to expand the outline when you want to look the code symbol,  and also can folding it when needed.

By the way, why the outline view can not be maximize in the side bar when in expanding state ?

title: Cursor Location inaccurate on second monitor.
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.27.2 
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise 1803 Build 17134.345

Steps to Reproduce:
Pre Condition: 
Dual monitor setup. Screen 1 on top of Screen 2. 
Screen 1 Scale set to 150%
Screen 2 Scale set to 125%

1. Have Visual studio code open with a python script on Screen 1.
2. throw down some p-thon
3. Move the cursor back a few char positions and make note. 
4. Pull the vs code app from Screen 1 to Screen 2 where it resizes. 
5. Note the relocation of the cursor. 
6. Modify your code and note that the cursor does not match the output text. 

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Unsure. 

Note: I am unsure if this is a Windows 10 bug or Visual Studio code bug but I have not noticed this on other software at the time of this bug report. In the meantime I have aligned my screen scaling as a work around for this issue.

title: Ability to move custom views across containers

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
Extensions contributing view containers and views are providing a feature allowing users to choose the view container into a contributed view can be shown. Under the hood extensions register multiple same views with different ids for each location and use the when context to define the visibility. This is cumbersome from an implementation perspective also causing issue like https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/57422

Cleaner way is to VS Code OOB provides support to move contributed views across view containers

title: Ctrl+Down gets stuck when a folded section is reached.
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.28.1
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows 10 [Version 10.0.17134.228]

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Fold any section (in any language).
2. Press Ctrl+Down to move down until the top of the screen reaches the folded section. You will notice further scrolling is not possible. This only happens with Ctrl+Down. The Ctrl+Up seems to be fine.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Occurs Always.**

title: When editing css / scss, an option to not inserting blank line within braces.
escaped quotation marks doubles in launch.json when I debug
body:
Hello vscode community, thanks for your amazing work.

I ran into issues as I was trying to debug my python code that involves sub arguments. For instance, a simplified version of my commandline is:
```commandprompt
python foo.py --my_rules replace_text:"current string":"replacement string"
```
So when I try to debug, I have my launch.json as:
```json
"configurations":[
  {
     "name":"my debugger",
     "program":"foo.py",
      "args":[ "--my_rules","replace_text:\"current string\":\"replacement string\""]
  }
]
```
which should be equivalent to my ideal CMD input.
However, this is what I got in my terminal:
```commandprompt
...python.exe {myworkplace}\foo.py --my_rules replace_text:""current string"":""replacement string""
```

and thus creates error taking the arguments since `\"` creates `""`. BTW I tried different spacing as well. It is not a expected JSON behavior and I couldn't find any answers from StackOverflow. I would really appreciate if someone can help. 

Best regards

title: Adjust color theme based on system dark mode setting (Windows/Mac)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Feature request: It would be cool if I could register in VSCode a preferred light workbench color theme and a separate preferred dark color them. Then VSCode could automatically switch to my chosen light or dark theme based on the system-wide Mojave dark appearance option.

title: Show warning for Chinese/Russian/Japanese languages in issue reporter
body: Similar to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-probot/issues/16, we could include some simple logic for detecting foreign languages and warn against using non-English languages in issue reporting.

title: VS Code changes indention of current line
body:
I am using VS Code 1.28.2 on Windows 10. I'm editing an HTML file indented with tabs. But I have HTML `
` sections which I want indented with spaces.

Let's say I have the following code:

```html

  foo //I press  at the end of this line


```
* When I open the file VS Code detects I use tabs. Fine.
* When I hit `` at the end of the line that says "foo", VS Code indents the next line. Fine.
* VS Code isn't smart enough to realize that I want to indent the next line with spaces instead of a tab, because it already got into its head that I want to use tabs everywhere. It's not smart enough to realize that the previous line `  foo` was indented with spaces. It uses a tab for the next line. But OK, I can live with that, too. It's understandable.
* **Bug:** What isn't acceptable is that VS Code _changes the indention of the existing line_ from spaces to tabs!!

Yes, when I hit `` after "foo", it not only indents the next line but _changes the indention that comes before `foo`_ from spaces to tabs.

```html

  foo //bug: the two spaces have been converted to a tab!
  //this new line also has a tab, which I don't want but can accept for now


```

VS Code has no business of changing the existing line. I simply hit `` to go to the next time. This is a huge problem, and it has likely corrupted a bunch of lines in this file because I didn't catch on to what it was doing.

Sure, we have auto-indent features to try to automatically insert indent on the _following_ line, but please don't mess with the line I already have.

How can I turn this off?

title: Task Manager: provide the ability to reuse custom problem matchers

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: I have several related tasks that share a custom output format.  I'd like to be able to define a problem matcher for this format once and reference it in multiple tasks like I can for built-in matchers, eg. `"problemMatcher": "$my-matcher"`.
